data.text: @PaulKingsley7 @rachbarnhart Not discrediting cdc. Saying though there are more things to consider than one measure

@tscheske @rachbarnhart “just because the CDC says”
You know the 10,000+ career EXPERTS who work at the Centers for Disease Control are not on the same scientific standing as Googlers who have spent *hours* doing “research”.
They are the worlds experts.
Perfect: no.
If you disagree: show expertise.
@rachbarnhart @PaulKingsley7 Right on point. Just because cdc says the best way to mitigate spread is masks doesn't mean there are no consequences or better approach. Don't focus on single measures.
@PaulKingsley7 Except Omicron followed the same Hope-Simpson curve the other variants did. The mandates did nothing to change that.

@rachbarnhart Haven’t seen that position recently. It’s the extreme position the anti-maskers point to a lot, though. Haven’t seen folks decide to die on the hill of mandatory masking fur 2-year olds. Only anti’s.
There’s been recent research (I posted) about lower aerosols from preadolescents
@PaulKingsley7 @rachbarnhart And with due respect you’ve been bashing Rachel for months for saying something you now agree with because the CDC said it.
@PaulKingsley7 But it was Rachel who was saying that all along and y’all were lambasting her for it. Now that the CDC changed suddenly you can see what she was saying all along?

@PaulKingsley7 No not what I was saying. It's hypocritical to insist masking toddlers is needed Thursday, but not Friday.

That is the level of discourse I've seen on this subject - no nuance, no room for uncertainty or compassion. Just "you're wrong, I'm right. The science."

@rachbarnhart With due respect, your point was bashing medtwitter for saying because CDC guidance has changed, with data, with science, it’s hypocritical to change behavior, such as masking in schools, etc.

It’s not, hypocritical, it’s rational.
